metadata.author: Yang Han, Xinxin Li, Yan Yan, Ming-Hua Duan, Jian-Hong Xu
metadata.title: Identification, characterization, and functional prediction of circular RNAs in maize
metadata.abstract: Circular RNAs (circRNAs) are a new type of intracellular regulator that have been widely identified in animals and plants by high-throughput sequencing. However, there are still few functional studies on circRNAs in plants. To better understand maize circRNAs and their potential functions, we identified 1199 circRNAs in maize from RiboMinus RNA-Seq transcriptome data, and found distinct features of splicing site selection bias, longer flanking introns, and miniature inverted-repeat transposable element (MITE) insertions in flanking introns in maize circRNAs compared to other plant circRNAs. In total, 31 and 36 orthologous circRNAs were identified in rice and maize, respectively, but the orthologous parental genes could not produce orthologous circRNAs, mostly because of long-sequence insertions/deletions at flanking introns and approximately 24.3% of them contained MITE sequences. The majority of maize circRNAs showed high diversity of expression under different treatments and/or in different genetic backgrounds, implying that circRNAs could be involved in various regulatory networks. Twenty-six ecircRNAs were predicted to contain one or more target mimics, and 229 circRNAs had high coding potential, indicating that circRNAs could perform peptide-encoding functions in plants. These results will broaden understanding of the roles of circRNAs in plants and support further functional work on maize.

introduction: Circular RNAs (circRNAs) are a new type of intracellular regulator that have been widely identified in animals and plants by high-throughput sequencing. However, there are still few functional studies on circRNAs in plants. To better understand maize circRNAs and their potential functions, we identified 1199 circRNAs in maize from RiboMinus RNA-Seq transcriptome data, and found distinct features of splicing site selection bias, longer flanking introns, and miniature inverted-repeat transposable element (MITE) insertions in flanking introns in maize circRNAs compared to other plant circRNAs. In total, 31 and 36 orthologous circRNAs were identified in rice and maize, respectively, but the orthologous parental genes could not produce orthologous circRNAs, mostly because of long-sequence insertions/deletions at flanking introns and approximately 24.3% of them contained MITE sequences. The majority of maize circRNAs showed high diversity of expression under different treatments and/or in different genetic backgrounds, implying that circRNAs could be involved in various regulatory networks. Twenty-six ecircRNAs were predicted to contain one or more target mimics, and 229 circRNAs had high coding potential, indicating that circRNAs could perform peptide-encoding functions in plants. These results will broaden understanding of the roles of circRNAs in plants and support further functional work on maize.

Abstract: Circular RNAs (circRNAs) are a new type of intracellular regulator that have been widely identified in animals and plants by high-throughput sequencing. However, there are still few functional studies on circRNAs in plants. To better understand maize circRNAs and their potential functions, we identified 1199 circRNAs in maize from RiboMinus RNA-Seq transcriptome data, and found distinct features of splicing site selection bias, longer flanking introns, and miniature inverted-repeat transposable element (MITE) insertions in flanking introns in maize circRNAs compared to other plant circRNAs. In total, 31 and 36 orthologous circRNAs were identified in rice and maize, respectively, but the orthologous parental genes could not produce orthologous circRNAs, mostly because of long-sequence insertions/deletions at flanking introns and approximately 24.3% of them contained MITE sequences. The majority of maize circRNAs showed high diversity of expression under different treatments and/or in different genetic backgrounds, implying that circRNAs could be involved in various regulatory networks. Twenty-six ecircRNAs were predicted to contain one or more target mimics, and 229 circRNAs had high coding potential, indicating that circRNAs could perform peptide-encoding functions in plants. These results will broaden understanding of the roles of circRNAs in plants and support further functional work on maize.

claims: To better understand maize circRNAs and their potential functions, we identified 1199 circRNAs in maize from RiboMinus RNA-Seq transcriptome data, and found distinct features of splicing site selection bias, longer flanking introns, and miniature inverted-repeat transposable element (MITE) insertions in flanking introns in maize circRNAs compared to other plant circRNAs
key_statements: Circular RNAs are a new type of intracellular regulator that have been widely identified in animals and plants by high-throughput sequencing

To better understand maize circRNAs and their potential functions, we identified 1199 circRNAs in maize from RiboMinus RNA-Seq transcriptome data, and found distinct features of splicing site selection bias, longer flanking introns, and miniature inverted-repeat transposable element (MITE) insertions in flanking introns in maize circRNAs compared to other plant circRNAs

31 and 36 orthologous circRNAs were identified in rice and maize, respectively, but the orthologous parental genes could not produce orthologous circRNAs, mostly because of long-sequence insertions/deletions at flanking introns and approximately 24.3% of them contained miniature inverted-repeat transposable element sequences

The majority of maize circRNAs showed high diversity of expression under different treatments and/or in different genetic backgrounds, implying that circRNAs could be involved in various regulatory networks

31 and 36 orthologous circRNAs were identified in rice and maize, respectively, but the orthologous parental genes could not produce orthologous circRNAs, mostly because of long-sequence insertions/deletions at flanking introns and approximately 24.3% of them contained miniature inverted-repeat transposable element sequences

The majority of maize circRNAs showed high diversity of expression under different treatments and/or in different genetic backgrounds, implying that circRNAs could be involved in various regulatory networks
